Tutorial.1: In the following messages, an example will be described which will demonstrate how to use the information grid.
Tutorial.2: Example Scenario: 5 people will each be given a gift. Each gift needs to be wrapped in each person's favorite color. No one can receive the same gift or the same color of wrapping paper.
Tutorial.3: The grid for this example is displayed along with the tutorial. Go through the example by clicking next.
Tutorial.4: In this example, Brian's gift will not be combined wrapped with the Silver wrapping paper. Eliminate this option by marking it with an X (click once on the corresponding box).
Tutorial.5: The grid should look like this:
Tutorial.6: In this example, Amy will receive the Necklace. Select this option by marking it with an O (click twice on the corresponding box).
Tutorial.7: The grid should look like this:
Tutorial.8: Other combinations will need to be eliminated based on previous decisions. Since Amy will be given the Necklace (and no one else can have the same gift), the Necklace options should be eliminated for everyone else. Place X's for the Necklace options for everyone else.
Tutorial.9: The grid should look like this:
Tutorial.10: Thus, the information grid is used to note which combinations have been eliminated (X) or selected (O).
Tutorial.11: Note: The grid should only be marked if it is certain that an option should be eliminated or selected. To remove a marking, click on the selected box a third time.

Task Reminder.2: The grid provided to the left can be used to mark the options.
Task Reminder.3: Reminder: The purpose of the task is to assign each person a project role, office location, and amount of weekly project hours.

Tutorial.14:
Consider the following piece of information: Amy and Cierra only like Pink and Orange wrapping paper.
Based on the given information, the following assumptions can be made:
(A) Amy and Cierra should not be given any other wrapping paper colors.
(B) No one else should receive the Pink or Orange wrapping paper. Using either Pink or Orange paper for anyone else will require Amy's or Cierra's gift to be wrapped in a color that they dislike.
Tutorial.15: Mark the grid to reflect the new information.
Tutorial.16: (A) Amy and Cierra should not be given any other wrapping paper colors:
Tutorial.17: (B) No one else should receive the Pink or Orange wrapping paper:
Tutorial.18: Marked options should be copied over throughout the grid when applicable. Since the Necklace will be given to Amy, and Amy will receive either the Silver, Green, or Blue paper, these colors should also be eliminated from the Necklace column. Mark the grid reflect these deductions.
Tutorial.19: The grid should look like this:
Tutorial.20: Consider the next piece of information: Eric wants the Skateboard or the Sweater. Mark the grid to reflect the new information.
Tutorial.21: The grid should look like this:
Tutorial.22: However, the Skateboard and the Sweater are quite large. There is not enough Silver or Green paper to wrap either of these gifts. Mark the grid to reflect the new information.
Tutorial.23: The grid should look like this:
Tutorial.24: There are marked options that can be copied to other parts of the grid. Since Eric will receive the Skateboard or Sweater, and these gifts can only be wrapped in Silver or Green paper, these colors should be eliminated from the column for Eric. Mark these deductions in the grid.
Tutorial.25: The grid should look like this:
Tutorial.26: Additional deductions can be made based on the grid. 4 of the 5 colors have been eliminated for Derek and for Eric. Therefore, there is only one remaining color for each of these people. Mark the grid to identify which colors should be used for Derek and Eric.
Tutorial.27: The grid should look like this:
Tutorial.28: As previously mentioned, mark the remaining boxes for that particular category with an X. Note that the group of boxes on the right side of the grid represent the WRAPPING PAPER category. 3 options can be eliminated for this category. Place an X where options should be eliminated; these should be placed in a row or column containing an O).
Tutorial.29: The grid should look like this:
Tutorial.30: The grid now indicates that the only available color for Brian is Green. This option should be marked in the grid.
Tutorial.31: The tutorial will now explain how to identify possible mistakes.
Tutorial.32: There should never be all X's for a particular category (i.e. gift or color). In the example shown below, all of the configurations are incorrect.
Tutorial.33: There should never be more than one O for a category (i.e. gift or color). In the example shown below, all of the configurations are incorrect.

Tutorial.1: First things first. Let's go over how to use the information grid. I'll use a running example to teach you how to use the information grid.
Tutorial.2: Imagine you are deciding which gift to give to 5 friends. You also want to wrap each gift in the friend's favorite color. Each gift should be special so no one can receive the same gift or the same color of wrapping paper.
Tutorial.3: The grid for this example is displayed along with the tutorial. Let us go through the example together.
Tutorial.4: Brian hates the color Silver so you shouldn't wrap his gift in this color. Please eliminate this option by marking it with an X (click once on the corresponding box).
Tutorial.5: Your grid should look like this:
Tutorial.6: Amy loves jewelry so you decide to give her the Necklace. Please select this option by marking it with an O (click twice on the corresponding box).
Tutorial.7: Your grid should look like this:
Tutorial.8: Other combinations will need to be eliminated based on previous decisions. Since Amy will be given the Necklace (and no one else can have the same gift), the Necklace options should be eliminated for everyone else. Place X's for the Necklace options for everyone else.
Tutorial.9: The grid should look like this:
Tutorial.10: As you can see, the information grid is used to note which combinations you have eliminated (X) or selected (O).
Tutorial.11: And please be careful - only mark the grid if you're certain that an option should be eliminated or selected. If you want to remove a marking, click on the selected box a third time.
Tutorial.12: Okay, [Name]! That concludes the basic training on how to use the grid. I think you're ready for the task.

Task Reminder.2: You can use the grid provided to the left to mark your options as you progress
Task Reminder.3: And remember, your goal is to assign each candidate a project role, office location, and weekly project hours.

Clue_Ins.1: Here are 5 major pieces of information that you might want to consider.

Redundant_Ins.1: I'm confident you have enough information to make an appropriate decision.
Redundant_Ins.2: However, I will give you some additional information to make decision making easier.

Submit.1: Okay, now that you've seen all the information I have, it's time to submit your final decisions!
Submit.2: Please show me the team assignments for each person using the table:
Submit.3: When you're happy with the final decisions, please click the 'Submit' button to  enter the team assignments.

Conclusion.1: Thanks, [Name]! I appreciate all your hard work.
Conclusion.2: It's been a pleasure working with you.
Conclusion.3: You will be redirected to Qualtrics shortly.

Look closely at the group of boxes on the right side of the grid which represent the WRAPPING PAPER category. 3 options can be eliminated here. Place an X where options should be eliminated (hint: look at the row or column where there is an O).
Tutorial.28: The grid should look like this:
Tutorial.29: Now, we see that the only available color for Brian is Green.This option should be marked in the grid.
Tutorial.30: Now, let's go over some possible mistakes you should look out for.
Tutorial.31: There should never be all X's for a particular category (i.e. gift or color). In the example shown below, all of the configurations are incorrect.
Tutorial.32: There should never be more than one O for a category (i.e. gift or color). In the example shown below, all of the configurations are incorrect.
Tutorial.33: Okay, [Name]! That concludes the tutorial. I think you're ready for the task.
